Award.AwardTitle: Travel Funds for Junior Scientists to attend the International Plant Growth Substances Association Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide travel funds to allow several graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and junior faculty working in U.S. institutions to attend an international conference on plant growth and development in Tarragona, Spain from June 28-July 2, 2010.

Plant growth substances (also referred to as plant hormones) regulate almost all aspects of growth and development, beginning with seed germination through the growth of the parent plant to the development of the flower and the formation of seeds. The scientific program includes 80 invited speakers from 20 countries, each a leader in his or her respective field, together with additional investigators who were selected as speakers after the submission of Scientific Abstracts. Over 500 poster presentations will be made.

Intellectual Merit.
This important conference will be an opportunity for young investigators working in the area of plant hormones to be exposed to the latest, ground-breaking research in the field. This is the only international meeting of its kind, devoted entirely to plant hormones, and it will stimulate research on plant growth substances in the U. S. These molecules have long been established as important for U.S. agriculture, and our understanding of the cellular and molecular basis of their action is essential for the long-term sustainability of agriculture.

Broader Impacts.
This award will provide an opportunity for young scientists to establish meaningful relationships with their counterparts from elsewhere in the world. These interactions could include the setting up of collaborative research program that will have a lasting impact on the careers of these junior scientists. Applications from individuals from minority-serving institutions and those with disadvantaged status are especially encouraged. A committee of three IPGSA Council members will be responsible for evaluating applicants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the travel of sixteen junior scientists from U.S. institutions to the International Plant Growth Substances Association (IPGSA) Conference in Tarragona, Spain in June 2010. This conference showcasing research on plant growth substances is held every three years, rotating between the continents of Europe, America, and Asia or Australia. The last time this conference was held in America was in 2007 when it was held in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. The last time the conference occurred in the United States was in 1995 when it was held in Minneapolis. The conference in 2013 will be held in Shanghai, China.

The conference in Spain was attended by 565 participants from 34 countries, so it was truly international. The most participants came from the home country, Spain, with Japan having the second highest number of participants. There were 46 attendees from the United States, of which sixteen were categorized as "junior scientists". All these sixteen junior scientists received funding from this travel grant. These individuals were assistant professors, (4), postdoctoral fellows (5), graduates students (5) and undergraduates (2). Each had submitted an application to a committee of three IPGSA council members in the US. The applications included a cv, Abstract of their scientific presentation, and a letter requesting financial assistance. The committee allocated funds depending on the strength of the application, and financial need. Participants received between $600 and $1500 each, that was applied towards airfare and/or accommodation. 

Each participant contributed an oral or poster presentation on their research in the area of plant hormones and other growth substances,  and during the five day conference attended lectures given by a number of very well respected plant biochemists and molecular biologist from around the world. Many speakers spoke of their ground-breaking work on plant hormone signaling and plant hormone crosstalk.  For most of the junior scientists it was the first opportunity to hear many of these "big names" in the plant growth substances field. Many of the junior scientists were able to meet colleagues working in their respective, sometimes very specialized, research areas. New collaborations were initiated and others were strengthened.

Many of the junior scientists  remarked that they would not have been able to attend this conference had it not been for the support from this travel grant. All participants commented on how important they felt the conference had been to their research careers. 

 

Broader imapcts.

All participants were junior scientists working or studying in U.S. institutions, and are in the formative years of their careers. They came from eleven different institutions in the U.S. Of the sixteen people supported by this award seven were female, four were Hispanic, and one was African American.
